awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Dr. Stuart J. Rowan from University of Chicago to develop synthetic methods to build new polymer architectures and to study how these architectures impact polymer properties.  Conventionally, polymers or long chain molecules are prepared from smaller molecules that are joined together by carbon-carbon covalent bonds.  Covalent bonding occurs when pairs of electrons are shared by atoms and it constitutes the basic building principle for all of organic chemistry. The approach in this work is rather unique because the repeating units in the targeted polymers are not covalently bonded to one another, yet cannot be separated unless covalent bond breakage occurs.  Essentially, the monomer units are interlocked together like individual pieces in a metal chain or necklace. The molecular version of two interlocked rings is called a catenane and, when they are liked together the overall structure is a polycatenane (it looks like a metal chain). A related interlocked polymer in which a long polymer molecule is threaded through a ring molecule, like beads on a string, is called a polyrotaxane. Such interlocked polymeric materials may have unique physical properties and potential applications in the areas of molecular electronics, energy absorbing materials, nanorecording and optical bioimaging.  The activities associated with this award increase broadening participation and enable training of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in synthetic organic chemistry and polymer chemistry.  The outreach program 'Natures Materials' is created as a part of the Cleveland Museum of Natural History's Martin Luther King Discover Day which demonstrates how natural polymers are used everyday. 

Both polycatenanes and polyrotaxanes consist of components that are interlocked together and held in place with a mechanical bond.  In this research, an investigation on how the structure of the components can be used to impact product distribution, molecular weight, and the resulting properties of polycatenanes is conducted.  In addition, research activities expand the types of interlocked polymers that can be accessed via the metallosupramolecular template approach to doubly-threaded poly[3]rotaxanes and slide ring gels.  The access to such new interlocked polymeric structures, along with a better structure/property understanding of such systems, allows the development of materials with the potential to exhibit an unusual property matrix.  These structures open the door to new polymeric actuators and materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Mechanically interlocked polymers (MIPs) are macromolecules that incorporate a mechanical bond. A polycatenane is a MIP in which the mechanical bond is a consequence of interlocked rings, while a polyrotaxane is a MIP in which a linear component with stopper groups on the end is threaded through a ring. The interlocked nature of these architectures can result in high mobility of their components that can give rise to unique property profiles. This project, led by Dr. Stuart J. Rowan (University of Chicago) and funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, primarily focused on MIPs formed only from interlocked rings (think a macroscopic chain) called poly[n]catenanes. This was achieved by self-assembling bis-ligand-containing monomers (one macrocyclic and one linear) with a metal ion to form a metallosupramolecular polymer. The linear monomers have reactive chain ends that when reacted yield cyclic-, linear- and/or branched poly[n]catenanes upon removal of the templating metal ion (Image a). The Rowan group investigated how monomer structure impacted the poly[n]catenane synthesis and showed that smaller monomers inhibited formation of the linear poly[n]catenanes resulting in efficient synthesis of branched poly[n]catenanes. Coarse-grained modelling studies were undertaken to explore the unusual properties of poly[n]catenanes. For example, modeling the poly[n]catenane?s dynamics in the melt showed that (up to a point) the viscosity decreases with increasing ring size (molecular weight), in contrast to the behavior of typical polymer melts.  It is proposed that inter-ring correlations ("topological friction") between the doubly-threaded rings causes this behavior.

Polycatenane networks (Image b) were prepared by reacted different ratios of a tetratopic crosslinker and a doubly threaded pseudo[3]rotaxane with a ditopic monomer to yield covalent gels with the varying amounts of crosslinking doubly-threaded interlocked macrocycles. The mechanical properties of these slide-ring polycatenane gels varied with the amount of macrocycle incorporated in the gel showing an additional relaxation process that is attributed to movement of the polymer chains through the catenated rings. Furthermore, the presence of the rings increases the rate of poroelastic draining at longer timescales. Finally, to move toward doubly-threaded polyrotaxane-based MIPs it was important to identify moieties that can act as stopper groups for the large rings that are of interest. A series of doubly threaded [3]rotaxanes were synthesized (Image c). By tightening the ring it was possible access [3]rotaxanes with a wide range of kinetically stability, laying the synthetic groundwork for a range of higher order doubly-threaded interlocked architectures.


Last Modified: 09/04/2023
Modified by: Stuart J Rowan

Image
  • (a) Poly[n]catenane synthesis and modelling, (b) synthesis of slide ring polycatenane gels and (c) schematic synthesis of doubly threaded [3]rotaxanes and atomistic model.
    Stuart Rowan
    Copyrighted
    Stuart J Rowan
    Interlocked Polymers
por.por_txt_cntn:
Mechanically interlocked polymers (MIPs) are macromolecules that incorporate a mechanical bond. A polycatenane is a MIP in which the mechanical bond is a consequence of interlocked rings, while a polyrotaxane is a MIP in which a linear component with stopper groups on the end is threaded through a ring. The interlocked nature of these architectures can result in high mobility of their components that can give rise to unique property profiles. This project, led by Dr. Stuart J. Rowan (University of Chicago) and funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, primarily focused on MIPs formed only from interlocked rings (think a macroscopic chain) called poly[n]catenanes. Polycatenane networks (Image b) were prepared by reacted different ratios of a tetratopic crosslinker and a doubly threaded pseudo[3]rotaxane with a ditopic monomer to yield covalent gels with the varying amounts of crosslinking doubly-threaded interlocked macrocycles. Finally, to move toward doubly-threaded polyrotaxane-based MIPs it was important to identify moieties that can act as stopper groups for the large rings that are of interest. A series of doubly threaded [3]rotaxanes were synthesized (Image c). By tightening the ring it was possible access [3]rotaxanes with a wide range of kinetically stability, laying the synthetic groundwork for a range of higher order doubly-threaded interlocked architectures.
